context_of_use: The use case describes how an IFA administrator accesses and views an overview dashboard in the web application to easily check information regarding leagues and teams.
stakeholders_and_interests: IFA administrator: Wants quick and consolidated access to leagues and teams information through a dashboard.
CIO: Wants the administrator interface to support transparency and efficient monitoring of leagues and teams.
IFA organization: Wants administrators to have accurate and up-to-date visibility of leagues and teams information.
description: This use case specifies how an IFA administrator accesses and views an administrative dashboard within the web application that presents consolidated information about leagues and teams to support efficient monitoring and checking of this information.
triggering_event: The IFA administrator decides to open the administrator dashboard in the web application in order to check leagues and teams information.
preconditions: The IFA administrator has a valid administrator account in the system.
The IFA administrator is successfully authenticated in the web application.
Leagues and teams information relevant to the IFA administrator is stored and available in the system.
The web application is operational and reachable by the IFA administrator.
postconditions: The administrator dashboard is displayed to the IFA administrator.
The administrator dashboard presents current leagues and teams information to the IFA administrator.
The system records that the IFA administrator has accessed the administrator dashboard for monitoring purposes.
assumptions: It is assumed that the IFA administrator accesses the administrator dashboard through a standard web browser interface of the IFA Web Application.
It is assumed that authentication is handled by an existing Authentication Service and that this use case starts after successful login, even though login is not detailed in the given requirements.

It is assumed that the leagues and teams information presented on the administrator dashboard is read-only in the context of this use case and that any creation or modification of such data is handled by other use cases.
It is assumed that the system retrieves leagues and teams information from internal data stores already populated by other processes or use cases.
It is assumed that only users with the IFA administrator role can access the administrator dashboard.
It is assumed that the information shown on the dashboard is limited to leagues and teams, as explicitly mentioned in the requirement text.
It is assumed that performance expectations such as fast responses are applicable but are enforced by non-functional requirements outside this specific use case.

It is assumed that the IFA administrator may navigate to the administrator dashboard from an internal menu or landing page after login, even though the exact navigation path is not specified in the requirement text.
requirements_met: The system shall provide an administrator dashboard in the web application for IFA administrators.
The system shall allow an IFA administrator to view leagues information on the administrator dashboard.
The system shall allow an IFA administrator to view teams information on the administrator dashboard.
The system shall restrict access to the administrator dashboard to authenticated users with the IFA administrator role.
The system shall present leagues and teams information on the administrator dashboard in a consolidated overview suitable for quick checking by the IFA administrator.
outstanding_issues: The exact data elements and level of detail for leagues information to be displayed on the administrator dashboard are not defined.
The exact data elements and level of detail for teams information to be displayed on the administrator dashboard are not defined.
The required refresh strategy for the administrator dashboard (manual refresh versus automatic periodic updates) is not specified.
The required maximum response time for loading the administrator dashboard is not explicitly defined.
The layout, widgets, and visualization style (tables, charts, summaries) for displaying leagues and teams information on the administrator dashboard are not specified.
The access control policy for administrators with different permission levels, if any, for viewing parts of the dashboard is not defined.
main_flow: 1. IFA administrator selects the option to access the administrator dashboard in the web application → System receives the request to open the administrator dashboard for the authenticated IFA administrator.
2. IFA administrator waits while the dashboard loads → System retrieves current leagues information relevant to the IFA administrator from its data stores.
3. IFA administrator continues to wait while information is prepared → System retrieves current teams information relevant to the IFA administrator from its data stores.
4. IFA administrator views the loaded dashboard → System composes an overview dashboard containing the retrieved leagues and teams information for display.
5. IFA administrator reviews leagues and teams information on the dashboard → System renders the administrator dashboard in the web application interface for the IFA administrator.

6. IFA administrator may continue to observe or scroll through the dashboard content → System maintains the display of the administrator dashboard and keeps the retrieved leagues and teams information available for viewing during the session.
alternative_flows: AF-1 (from Step 1): If the IFA administrator is already located on a default landing page that includes the administrator dashboard as the initial view, the IFA administrator opens the web application and is directly presented with the administrator dashboard without selecting a separate option, after which the flow continues from Step 4.

AF-2 (from Step 6): If the IFA administrator requests a manual refresh of the visible information while remaining on the administrator dashboard, the system re-retrieves current leagues and teams information from its data stores and re-renders the administrator dashboard with updated information, after which the flow continues from Step 5.
exception_flows: EF-1 (from Step 1): If the system determines that the current user is not authenticated as an IFA administrator when attempting to access the administrator dashboard, the system denies access to the administrator dashboard and redirects the user to an appropriate authentication or authorization error page, and the use case ends without displaying the administrator dashboard.

EF-2 (from Steps 2 and 3): If the system cannot retrieve leagues or teams information due to a data access or internal error, the system logs the error, displays an error message indicating that leagues and teams information cannot be loaded at this time, and does not display incomplete or inconsistent dashboard content, and the use case ends after presenting the error message.

EF-3 (from Step 5): If the system takes longer than the configured maximum loading time to render the administrator dashboard, the system displays a timeout or temporary unavailability message to the IFA administrator instead of the dashboard content, and the use case ends without successfully presenting the administrator dashboard.
information_for_steps: 1. Administrator identity, administrator session identifier, dashboard access request parameters.
2. Leagues identifiers, leagues names, leagues status attributes, leagues configuration attributes relevant for display.
3. Teams identifiers, teams names, associated league identifiers, teams status attributes relevant for display.
4. Aggregated leagues data, aggregated teams data, layout configuration for administrator dashboard overview.
5. Rendered dashboard view, formatted leagues and teams information, pagination or scrolling metadata as applicable.
6. Current dashboard view state, session context, any cached leagues and teams data used for continuous display.
